title: WhyFhy
author: WhyFhy
content: I'm looking to get your insights on the evolution of the Lightning Network over the past couple of years. As someone who hasn't used it in a while, I'm curious to know how it has matured and evolved during this time.Back when I last used it, the Lightning Network was still in its early stages, with a lot of potential but also many challenges to overcome. I remember there were concerns about liquidity, routing, and the overall user experience. I could poke stuff and break it, but I wouldn't understand why it broke in the first place. So, for those of you who have been actively using or following the Lightning Network, I'd love to hear your thoughts. How has the network evolved? Have there been significant improvements in terms of scalability, speed, and fees? How about the user experience - has it become more user-friendly?Also, I'm interested in any new applications or use cases that have emerged as a result of these developments. Are there any standout projects or initiatives that you think are worth highlighting?I'm looking for a new project to participate in or conjure up something new all around and want to go back into LNAre we still on #reckless or has that image faded?

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: WhyFhy on June 24, 2023, 12:46:31 PMBack when I last used it, the Lightning Network was still in its early stages, with a lot of potential but also many challenges to overcome.I'm more or less in the same boat, I haven't used LN as much as I would have liked lately, and that's mostly because the services I use don't accept it. The one major change (for me) is that BlueWallet stopped offering custodial LN. This was one of my favourite wallets.There are now more exchanges that accept LN, but I haven't used them yet (I don't need an exchange to use LN).
